He felt heavy with his thoughts, but then he suddenly experienced a strong feeling that took over him. It felt like a spark igniting inside him, spreading warmth through his body. Everything inside him softened, and tears filled his eyes. He fell to the ground right there.

He knelt in the middle of the square, bowed down, and kissed the dirty ground with joy. Then he got up and bowed again.

“Looks like he’s drunk,” a young guy nearby said.

People around him laughed.

“He’s going to Jerusalem, saying goodbye to his kids and his country. He’s bowing to the whole world and kissing the streets of St. Petersburg,” added a slightly drunk worker.

“He’s pretty young!” someone else said.

“And a gentleman,” another person said seriously.

“Who knows who’s a gentleman these days?” 

These comments made Raskolnikov pause, and the words “I am a murderer,” which almost came out, faded away. He listened quietly to the remarks and, without looking back, turned down a street towards the police office. On his way, he saw something that didn’t surprise him; he had expected it. When he bowed down again in the Hay Market, he noticed Sonia standing about fifty steps away, hiding behind one of the wooden stalls.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov experiences a profound emotional moment of humility and connection to the world, kneeling and kissing the ground, before heading towards the police office.
